you're plateauing. everyone has a weight where they plateau - for me it's 105lbs.
>buy digital scale for 20 buckaroos
>avoid shocking your body too early
>incrementally stagger down your calorie deficit over a week
>recoup calories within 2-3 days so that your body doesn't think you're going into starvation mode
>repeat lowering plateau threshold
my original plateau was 106lbs last year, took 4 months to drop it down to 103-104lbs

posts.com:
>>17412632
>>17412667
For a 1st time home job + by yourself it looks pretty good. If a pro did it i world demand money back, but thats spending $300 not $15 sooo....
Notes:
You will be shocked how different it looks toned re: white, get some purple in asap (warning, you want the 1st few days to look purple tinged to get good white)
If you are going to bleach again give it a few weeks + high intensity repair products, otherwise your hair will be even more giga bleach fucked (this is from 1 thin hair mf to another).
From here you are going to need to use a surprising amount of leave in conditioners and shit. Go sulfate free too. Dont just hope it will be fine, your hair is so thin its going to be weak af and break and start looking noticeable less + frizzy/splitendy
(Also, potentially the best non olaplex product ive ever used is too cool for school egg mask)

You obvs did it in a cold room or had less heat etc on the ends because they are so much darker. In the same vein Id be worried that the base of the hairs are overprocessed and are going to be brittle since you obvs didnt balance times (against scalp processes faster due to heat). Next time will be hard because you need to do the roots, but also completely avoid the previous base since it would be overprocessed already.

Honestly, i know its expensive, but bleaching really is something pros do better. You can pull off 1 time yourself, but when it then comes to blending new growth in and evening it out band free any shitty or at home jobs makes it that much harder.
There is a reason that colour correction is more expensive than just plain bleaching, its to even out and fix up all the prev flaws and takes much much longer than just doing it well to begin with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17413606
When I first got into watches they were the brand I loved to hate.

Now that I've settled down and I know what I like, I have a soft spot for that kind of thing. It's not trying to be anything more than what it is: a peacock piece for the true working man. The man who isn't laboring under the misapprehension that if he tries to pretend to be "stealth wealth" the rentier class will take pity on him and invite him into their club. He's not that midwit who spends a few month's car payments for the stainless steel 36mm watch with "horological heritage" in the vain hopes of impressing some guy whose brief favorable impression over his subtle taste might change his fate in that moment. He's not trying to play a 4D chess game to imply inherited wealth (without boasting! can't boast about weath! they don't like that!) to get in good with the people who profit of his labor, who will never even care what his oldest kid's name is.

It's a simpler equation: shiny = good. A man size watch for a man. His wife got it for him on their 5 year anniversary and he wears it with pride. The next anniversary on the way home from the warehouse he picks up a dozen carnations and a bottle of the good stuff: Layer Cake Bourbon Barrel Aged Cabernet Sauvignon. Neither of them cares much for wine but it's a special occasion. She didn't have to remind him this time. The watch is his reminder.

Maybe I'm just romanticizing poverty but to me it's more honest than the orient bambinos and the cocktail times that pass for "class" around here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In the past 30 days I have purchased six Casio watches, here I will rank them from my least to most liked:
>F84W (cool face design but too small and has comically tiny strap with insane taper)
>CA53W-1 (white calculator watch with inverted screen, fun aesthetics but pretty unusable buttons, poor legibility on screen, and no backlight)
>F91W (iconic design, still child sized but better than the F84W)
>W217H (adult-sized F91W, extremely comfortable)
>G-Shock GWM-5610-1U (functionally the greatest digital watch I've ever handled because of the solar charging, radio clock syncing, and extreme durability, but the aesthetics and comfort are middle of the road)
>AE1200 (aka Casio Royale, probably the sexiest watch Casio has ever made, and quite handsome on the wrist)
Ultimately I'd like to own a simple two-watch collection: one Casio digital, and one nice mechanical. Still narrowing down the field for the latter. For the former, it will be the Royale or the G-Shock.

I own a pair of their 310s. I love sprung boxy toes, but it isn't for everybody. That being said, it is one of my top 3 favorite pairs that I own alongside my Mister Lous and Whites 350 cruisers. Vibergs are undoubtedly great boots despite what mega autists on these generals will say. Of course theres always going to be people who say there's a "better" boot, but in the big picture Vibergs are the endgame for a lot of people who love leather boots. They realistically are only for casual/dress wear, but they work perfectly for that purpose. They have a large selection of relatively high quality leather for each of their lasts, and the amount of detail put into the stitching puts them slightly ahead of other well-known companies like Redwing and Whites. Nowadays if you want a top-shelf boot you'll have for life, you will have to accept spending at least $600-800.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I live in Japan.

>will Japanese people think I'm fashionable?
There's two ways of looking at it. On one hand you're (somewhat) blonde and blue-eyed, and obviously foreign, which means you'll be judged according to a totally separate set of criteria that all foreigners are subject to. Are you clean shaven? Are you over 180cm? Is there even the slightest bit of cohesion to what you're wearing (or, conversely, is your fit so uncoordinated and le randumb xDD as to be considered a "unique form of self-expression?") If you can answer yes to all three of those questions, you would be judged at the very least moderately fashionable by most Japanese people.
As for your outfit itself, on a Japanese person it would be considered basically the opposite of what is currently mainstream fashion. Right now, on the weekend, your average 18-35 year old Japanese guy is wearing a plain (or very close to plain) white or black tee one size too large, baggy slacks usually in a neutral color, casual athletic shoes (think Onitsuka Tigers, low top AF1s etc) in a matching color, and some kind of accessory, like a steel band watch or silver necklace. For outerwear they've usually got on neutral tone fleeces or thick longsleeves with minimalist designs, I haven't seen anybody wearing a leather jacket this year that wasn't obviously a part of some subculture.

>Do they really wear that often, do you see it on streets?
Yes. In the cities both men and women wear that kind of style of pants, usually beige/tan colored with white or matching shin-length socks. I personally hate it, but I learned early on that people here overuse socks in general. A lot of places will have you take your shoes off (usually restaurants but sometimes hotels and occasionally even businesses) and it's considered impolite or unsanitary to walk around barefoot or use whatever slippers they provide you with without socks, so a lot of the time you'll even see women with strappy shoes or peep toes using socks. I'm a footfag so it grinds my gears like nothing else.

It's different in the inaka, though. People there just don't give a fuck for better or for worse.

https://www.luckyscent.com/product/22713/lhomme-sage-by-divine


https://www.fragrantica.com/perfume/Divine/L-Homme-Sage-43.html


Check it's scores our first. Released in 2005, 4.29 out of 5, 200 votes. So it's well rated but compared to scents with thousands of votes from this year, it's very unknown
Go to the reminds me of section and it's blank. For good reason. I have never worn anything quite like this. It's got smoky elemi, cold snowy woods from the pine and leather but also a floral heart from immortelle and a pinch of ripe seductive fruit from the litchi. The reviews are glowing and for good reason.

It smells great, it performs well, it's rich,dark and seductive so it would fit fine in a goth setting, it's well under $200 and it's in stock.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1: Time for something a little different: Work scents for professionals and people in management age 25+. Let's be realistic, sometimes when you're in a high paying field there are rules and regulations and you can't express yourself as much as you'd like to clothing or scent wise. Especially if you're the boss and need to maintain a certain image of being approachable but also professional and in control.
What does this mean for your scents? Basically you're going to want quality scents that aren't as loud and don't have notes like cumin, heavy booze, heavy sexual musks, heavy smoke, rough ouds, etc. This may sound restrictive but as with most things in life its another change to be creative.

Let's start with spring. My choices are:
Hermes H24 EDP. The smell of hot irons, fresh linen, steam and green bananas

Loewe 7 Plata: Pink pepper, smokey mint, cedar and green incense

Creed Himalaya Ice cold woods,juniper, pepper and light musk


Issey Miyake Bleu: Beautiful mix of pine, rosemary, amber, florals and a light aquatic musk

These will smell amazing on a crisp match day. They aren't your standard Sauvage or BdC but they're still accessible and will last

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17413923
2: For the summer

Hermes Voyage EDP Pink pepper, tea notes, papyrus, florals,cedar


Les Indemodables Escale en Indonesie: A huge ambergris note, neroli and sandalwood

Goldfield and Banks Bohemian Lime: Peppery lime, Vetiver and cedar

Jourum Studios Gorseland: Gorse, Apple, neroli, green rose , lavender, coconut, grass


These four scents work well even when it's 95 degrees and you're sweating your ass off. They are light and fresh while still smelling mature, and they have echos of other more common fragrances. Escale is basically what niche Sauvage would smell like if it was good and well put together. Gorseland is the coconut from Virgin Island Water via gorse and with a more grassy floral dry down that smells like a Hermes Jardin fragrance.

These are fresh and captivating but still smell good with a suit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17413930
3: For the fall. This is the easiest season IMHO, you have so much room to work

Histories Des Parfums 1899 Hemingway: An evolution of the original Spicebomb DNA. Juniper opening to keep things fresh,dries down to cinnamon, sweet woods and dry amber and a ghost of blonde tobacco


Prada Luna Rossa Extreme: Clean soapy Prada style minimalism with a contrasting note of a blast of black pepper. absolutely love the contrast here.

Terre D'Hermes EDT Dirty orange, dusty ground up minerals, Vetiver and cedar. I prefer the EDT because it's rougher but the Parfum works well too


Polo Cologne Intense: Criminally ignored fragrance and one of the best blue fragrances on the market. Marries the sweet herbal opening of the original Polo to the shower gel wood drydown of YSL Y EDP/Parfum. Under rated because morons expected Polo Green 2, which admittedly isn't help by the name. This is the closest I'll get to an Ambroxan dominant frag. The sweet green herbs last into the drydown so it's never just a blue fragrance.


The reality of office temps is they're probably going to be the same year round. 70 in the spring, summer, fall, winter. It's all the same in first world countries. So you could probably wear the same things year round,but people associate certain smells with seasons. Grass and flowers in spring, citrus and ocean in the summer, dry woods in the fall, and more heavy woods, spices and vanillas in the winter. I think most people's wardrobes work fine in the fall, you can have temps ranging from 40-90 so there's room for everything

>>17413944
Lastly, winter

Prada Luna Rossa Black: An interesting bergamot earl grey opening quickly moving to an arid and bitter green galbanum that turns dusty and blends in with a powdery barbershop dry down. Clean, sweet and powdery

Divine L'homme Sage: Smells like money. Syrupy immortelle blending with rich golden cedar, nutty cardamom, sweet cold pine needles and a slight fruity touch of orange and litchi. Every note is distinct, absolute masterpiece of a fragrance. This is a work fragrance that I love wearing outside of work.

Lalique Lion EDP: One of the best kept secrets in the fragrance world, poor man's Bois Du Portugal. Citrus melange opening turns into smoky lavender and powdery sandalwood along with rich oakmoss and vanilla. Punches well above it's weight when it comes to cost.

Caron Pour Un Homme: Chose it as the opposite of Lalique Homme due to it's presentation of lavender. Here the lavender is rich, regal,plush and velvet. Blends perfectly with the rich sweet drydown of vanilla, amber and musk. This is as sweet and rich of a fragrance as I'd feel comfortable wearing at work, it also works as a date fragrance. But in cool temps it's easy to spray lightly and keep it under control, especially the newer formulations that are less dense and rich.
This is the spiritual precursor to YSL La Nuit IMHO


So there you have it, four seasons of diverse professional work fragrances to have you smelling unique, classy and professional.

>>17413571
if you are trying to go from light to dark, its best that you try to lift the hair (open up the keratin) as much as possible and then deposit as much as possible within a relatively short timeframe; you can also do this repeatedly at the cost of fragility. Regardless of what your hair looks like now, and what you want it to look like, you will end up buying a lifting product (people with dark hair use bleach/lightener), a toner to balance out color tones, and some type of dye. You can use semipermanent color but generally permanent leads to less "bleeding" (color fading and drainage). Do not buy box dye products. Go to Sally's or better yet a professional. Brands depend on what you want, and also research them before you put them on your hair to avoid adverse results or chemical reactions.

I'm >>17411102
Everything on the shelves is a boot. The ones you spotted are service boots, commonly made about 6" high.
And good leather shoes (starting about $300/msrp) are the opposite of sneakers in terms of comfort. They suck out of the box, but a few months in they feel great because they've molded to support your feet. Sneakers feel great out of the box, but get less and less comfortable as the cushioning flattens out.
If you're going secondhand, just wipe the inside down with some alcohol and you're good to go

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17412032
Depends on how worn in they are, but yeah, you're generally fine getting them used since the heat from your foot will just mold the leather to a new shape.
As for things to look out for, pay attention to the quality of the uppers ( thick full grain leather, no loose grain, no cracks), look for a stitched on sole (leather, vibram, or dainite), and look for a leather footbed.
It might be good to go to a high end store or a place that specializes in boots to get a feel for quality so you know what to look for as well

I'm 43 years old and wore these in the early 80's. So far I've seen them go from fashionable in the early 80's in the pop-punk scene to being completely out of fashion in the mid to late 80's to being retro in the early/mid-90's with alternative resurface of grunge and punk, then the "retro" went out of style and became cheesy in the late 90's only to resurface again in the mid 2000's with the hipsters then they faded out of style again in the late 2000's as being "hipster" was suddenly seen as uncool, only to then resurface again in a big way in the early 2010's but more in the mainstream pop crowd then to sort of die off again completely in the mid-2010's, then to resurface a little bit as acceptable again here and there where they aren't in style or cringe either in the past few years because nobody cares about anything anymore. I can say with confidence that, based on almost 50 years of my personal history with these sneakers, they will perpetually go out of style then back in style in a loop and that this trend probably will continue for many more decades. Why? I have no idea.

>>17413932
pretty subjective. biore is good but there's fake shit out there. for user experience, as an everyday face spf, I think eltamd is hard to beat. a recent study came out that suggested that the actives in hybrids (mineral x organic) may interact in a way that produces harmful byproducts but they didn't study all organics and notably the one they did study is not in elta, so I still use it

for outdoor sports I tend to favor minerals because they are infinitely photostable. you still have to reapply if you're sweating it off but if you don't have a chance to do so my personal experience has been that the cheaper waterproof minerals are better than just about anything short of skinnies conquer which is the undisputed champion of outdoor endurance sunscreen (the problem is it costs a fortune, is hard to find, and it can't be washed off for days)

>>17391064
I'm not sure moto is even motorcycles really. I think if you're leaning into motorcycle culture, you're missing the aesthetic, if you're leaning into guns, you're missing the aesthetic. The goofy little Japanese lorries fit the aesthetic better than an old cafe racer. This recent little set of moto collages is more about embracing practicality and personal taste to the abandonment of social expectations. There's a slightly autistic edge to it, it's intentionally weird. The gun is included like a fedora wearing neckbeard carrying a katana. Its also the abandonment of explicitly luxury aesthetic. A cohesive leather outfit and a new triumph screams money and luxury. You should be able to find motocore/motofunk in the ass end of Kazakhstan. It rides the line between basement NEET on his mom's scooter and 3rd world nomad hauling a deer carcass through the mountains to his home.

>>17396349
What kind of riding? You have three categories
Light weight
>Basically all dual sports
>300cc or lower
>Can go anywhere and everywhere
>Will not be as good for cruising on the highway
>Cannot carry as much luggage
>WR250R, CRF300L, DRZ400, KLX300
Mid weight
>Bigger engines that are good on highways and off road
>Heavier, can still go everywhere but you will struggle more on tighter stuff
>More luggage capacity
>Better for every day riding
>Tenere 700, new TransAlp when it comes out, KTM 790/890, KLR/DR 650
Big ADVs
>Generally the most comfortable bikes on the market
>Huge fuel range for eating up miles
>Can do off-road but size and weight become a limiting factor
>Generally very good on sealed roads and very fast due to large engines
>Boomer bikes
>BMW GS range, Honda Africa Twin, Ducati Desert X, 1290 adventure, Triumph Tiger

Usually people will buy light weight for doing multiday single track camping trips deep in the bush.
Midweight is for people that want to ride every day but still be able to go on adventures.
Big are for people who want to do cross country/multi country expeditions and larpers.

It's two different things. In the morning, you should use both a moisturizer and a sunscreen, or simply a moisturizer that contains a sunscreen. But at night, you need a separate moisturizer, because there's no sense in using a sunscreen at night. You can also get away with wearing a heavier moisturizer at night, or one that contains actives that are photo-sensitive (like retinol).

for acne prone skin i would recommend a zinc sunscreen, zinc is helpful in reducing and healing
existing breakouts. personally i use Attitude 30 SPF face and body mineral sunscreen. it has clean ingredients, it feels thick and a bit sticky but it goes on matte which i like. there's probably better zinc sunscreens in terms of texture out there, but i don't mind this if it's helping my acne. there isn't much of a white cast either. to remove it at the end of the day since it is waterproof, i have to dissolve it using a facial oil, or oil based cleanser, followed by my regular cleanser to clean off the oil.

i've heard people with acne prone skin get congestion and more acne with CeraVe, but other than that your list looks good. i'm trying out different moisturizers myself as i find everything breaks me out even other clean brands i've tried. i'm content with Laneige Cream Skin which i've been using for a year now. it doesn't break me out or aggravate the skin because it's a very basic moisturizer. It's a korean brand but i believe you can get it in France through Sephora.
If you have extra $ to splurge on a product I would recommend Estee Lauder's Advanced Night Repair serum, i got it as a sample and it drastically reduced my acne and improved my skin texture, i use it as a spot treatment too and it shrinks any breakouts overnight. Nothing has made as big a difference as that serum for me, combined with a better diet. it's marketed more as anti aging and firming etc but for me the difference it made in my acne and uneven texture which i've had my whole life is crazy. close to 100% clear skin now for the first time in probably a decade

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17371560
i haven't used CeraVe, but i've read reviews when i was looking for a better moisturizer. some described worsening acne/red patches, so i decided not to bother trying it. it could be exacerbating your issues if they're preexisting on your body? or perhaps you're having a negative reaction due to having more sensitive skin. i noticed i was more sensitive to products after using steroid creams as they thin out the skin.

i've struggled with eczema and acne my whole life (now more under control than ever, just get a few spots on occasion), the changes i've made to my diet that have helped were: reducing my intake of sugar and empty carbs, eating mostly whole foods (lots of vegs fruits beans rice oats, lots of antioxidant foods). for meat and dairy i try to get good quality when i can afford, same with organic produce. i try to drink lots of water. i take a zinc supplement by Vimergy, zinc helps with my skin both orally and topically (sunscreen) as some skin issues are worsened by a deficiency. 15 min in the sun for vitamin D.
all of this has improved my skin, my overall health and energy levels. i always regret slacking as i see the symptoms come back.
i highly recommend starting with diet changes as i need to rely less on products if the base health of my skin is good enough. i find it unsustainable to completely cut out sugars or bad foods you may enjoy, i allow myself to have them so long as my base diet is alright.

skincare:
AM:
Andalou Naturals sensitive cleansing foam
Estée Lauder Advanced night repair serum (helped improve residual skin issues)
Attitude SPF 30 mineral sunscreen
PM:
same, but switch out sunscreen for Laneige Cream Skin moisturizer.
final layer of Idoine moringa oil.

Alterra Execalm soothes any eczema flareups better than steroids for me.
I take less hot showers as it strips the skin. Sometimes i put sea salt in a spray bottle and spray my body to simulate the benefits i see when i visit the beach. hope something helps you here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17393342
Here's what I would consider swapping it out for:
am
> cerave's hydrating facial cleanser
Might want to consider just water (plus possibly a hydrating toner) in the morning if you experience irritation.
> skinceutical's vitamine c serum c e ferulic*
Personally I would ditch this entirely in favor of your niacinamide serum. Ascorbic acid can be drying af. Waste of money for sure
> the ordinary's niacinamide 10%
Niacinamide has been shown to be just effective and less irritating at concentrations of 2-5%. Consider swapping this out for something else but this will work in the meantime.
> the ordinary's natural moisturizing factors
> la roche posay's uvmune 400 invisible fluid without fragrance**
I don't use OT/LRP/Cerave but a lot of people like them so I have no opinion. Looks like your sunscreen provides good SPF protection.

pm
> cerave's hydrating facial cleanser
>tretinoin 0.05 sandwiched between your moisturizer followed up by additional moisturizer
As an FYI, 0.05 is kinda strong. Consider asking for 0.025 micro if you run into any issues.
> the ordinary's rose hip seed oil

The olive oil soap isn't necessary for removing sunscreen. As a rule of thumb, oil cleansing is best for removing water-resistant sunscreen or makeup. Your Cerave cleanser contains surfacants which helps remove the sunscreen. Also, oil cleansers are far less drying than oil-based soap and wash off easier. Less comedogenic as well. Olive oil can really mess up your skin. Good luck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17393640
Thanks! Admittedly skincare has been a process of trial and error for me but I've been into this stuff for like nine years haha. It sounds like you're at a good starting point (props to you for using sunscreen). If you don't mind me asking, what is your goal through using retinol? Differin (as opposed to other "retinol" products) would be your best OTC bet for things like acne.
If you're keen on oil cleansing, I would recommend using an oil cleanser in place of coconut oil and following up with a water-based cleanser. People who oil cleanse usually only do it at night. It's helped me a lot with blackheads personally. Products marketed as cleansing oils contain emulsifying agents, which help them wash off your skin (unlike straight-up oil). Coconut oil can be very comedogenic as well.
Some people really like Vitamin C and/or niacinamide for acne spots, but I'm not using either at the moment. In my opinion, it's best to be patient with the retinization process and refrain from adding additional actives in the meantime. Emphasize hydration if you get any skin flakes or irritation. You're off to a great start.
>>17393939
The Ordinary's claims surrounding Vitamin C and niacinamide have been debunked, but I recommend skipping Vitamin C for now because it can be sensitizing (especially in its ascorbic acid form). That stuff can be really rough on your skin if used too often. Here's a good article explaining the science behind it:
>https://www.paulaschoice.com/expert-advice/skincare-advice/skin-care-myths/can-niacinamide-and-vitamin-c-be-used-together.html

>>17400054
Nice, did you go to a dermatologist? Do you have acne or any other blemishes or is he just liberal with prescribing tret?
Anyways, when I first started out with tret I washed my face, and let it dry for 10-15 minutes before applying the tret. I only used it twice a week at first, then thrice a week and so on. At one point I used it too frequent, everything I did to my face burned, I was applying the most gentle moisturiser and my face was burning so I stopped it for a few days before resuming with tret. If you like you can buffer it, that means you apply a bit of moisturiser before applying tret and then applying moisturiser again.
It goes without saying but you are supposed to apply tret before going to sleep and don’t forget your sunscreen, I like Nivea Sun LSF 50 Mattierend.

Also, I don’t know what you end goal is but consistency is key, don’t expect anything within a few weeks or even months.

Reddit has its own Tretinoin subreddit, probably with its own beginners guide; you should definitely look into that.
Out of curiosity: what city are you from?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17410883
>soap+water
big mistake
Water draws substances into the leather, because it's porous. The soap may have drew some of it out, but the opposite could be true: It just drew it deeper into the material
The answer is to dab as much off as possible, use some baking soda overnight on the remaining spots, vacuum it up in the morning and just keeping doing that until the spots are gone. Gasoline also evaporates, so continue until you can't smell it, and then saddle soap + condition.

Bros, I have a dilemma.

I'm looking to purchase my first haute horologie sports watch and I've fallen in love with the design of the blue dial Vacheron Overseas 4500V. The blue is the most perfect blue I've ever seen on a watch, the Maltese Cross logo being used in almost every design aspect of the watch appeals a lot to my sensibilities in visual design and art (namely cohesion and unity of form), and it's so much more elegant and restrained than the Nautilus and Royal Oak to me, which I think matches my personality and dress much better. The waiting lists at boutiques are still really long, but the gray market prices where I am are finally right. I'm ready to make my purchase.

There's just one minor problem. I think it looks just a little too big on my wrist. I have a 15cm/6.5inch wrist that lays fairly flat, but the 4500V Overseas is a 41mm watch that wears more like a 42 or 43mm watch and pushes the limits of what my wrist can handle. Pic related, take into account that there is minor lens distortion going on in this photo. I may be too used to my dad's old 36mm Datejust but this really does just feel too big. Or is my brain just playing tricks on me and a watch wearing like this on a wrist is fine these days?

Assuming it really is just a hair too big, I have come up with the following alternative solutions, none of which feel terribly satisfying.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17411700
Option 1: Buy the 4500V anyways and cope like it's not oversized for my wrist.

Option 2: Downsize to the 37mm 2300V. The main problem I have with this is that even without the diamonds, it still looks like a woman's watch with the tapered hands and the smaller cleaner dial.

Option 3: Complete wildcard option, buy a Parmigiani Fleurier Tonda PF Rattrapante GMT instead, at 40mm and with a very useful dualtime complication for around the price of a gray market Overseas. I have not had the chance to try this one on in person yet but it should just barely fit my wrist given the Overseas feels like it just barely doesn't. My issues with this are that a): the design really does feel like it borders on too subtle and refined relative to the overseas and b): the watch has so many polished surfaces that it would drive me insane with how many fingerprints and scratches it would show after just a little daily wear.

Thoughts?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17412257
>How much of a big deal is regulating the powermatic 80? I always hear reviewers mention it, but it could just be a non issue
It's a non-issue. A powermatic 80 is basically just an ETA 2824 (one of the most common Swiss automatic movements) with a free-sprung balance, that is laser regulated from the factory.
A free-sprung balance is always a little harder to regulate, but if it were that difficult, then Rolexes would be a massive pain in the ass to service. ("Bro, just take it to your local watchmaker, anyone can service a Rolex.")

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Got a dress watch with an integrated metal bracelet, can't find any compatible leather straps online, still need to remove links anyway for a better fit... Anyone know about making your own straps or modifying?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17412418
It's a bit more complicated. Wrists are (practically) two-dimensional and uniquely shaped. For a general guide see picrel.
What i think matters more when determining the appropriate size of the watch is wrist width (how wide it is when looking at it from the top) and case diameter. You divide wrist width by phi (1.618) and you get your case diameter. Also the lug-to-lug distance should always be shorter than the wrist width so that the lugs don't hang over. Also take note that there are certain types of watches that are supposed to be bigger, like divers or pilot watches, and different watch shapes wear differently as well (one 40mm watch might look smaller than another 40mm watch).
